subject: Gardening
title: Tulip Mania: Flowers as Currency
description: A micro-lesson that makes Tulip Mania: Flowers as Currency usable.

hook.text: In 1637 Holland, a single tulip bulb sold for more than a canal house in Amsterdam. Then the market collapsed overnight.

buildup.text: Tulips arrived in Holland from Ottoman Turkey in the 1590s. Rare striped varieties became elite status symbols.

discovery.text: Speculation went wild. Futures contracts traded hands dozens of timesâ€”people buying bulbs they'd never even seen.

twist.text: The famous stripes were caused by a virus (tulip breaking virus). The most valuable tulips were literally sick flowers.

climax.text: Tulip mania is history's first speculative bubbleâ€”proof humans assign irrational value to any scarce natural thing.

punchline.text: History's first financial bubble was caused by sick flowers.

quiz.question: What caused the famous stripes in the most valuable tulip varieties?
options: Careful selective breeding over many generations
A virus (tulip breaking virus) that infected the flowers
Special soil conditions unique to Dutch polder land
